Phrase: My popularity, my happiness and sense of worth depend to no small extent upon my skill in dealing with people.

Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm that focuses on creating objects that contain data and methods to manipulate that data. It is a way of organizing and structuring software in a manner that is easy to understand, modify, and maintain.In OOP, objects are instances of classes, which are templates that define the properties and behaviors of objects. The properties of an object are represented by its attributes, while its behaviors are represented by its methods. One of the key features of OOP is encapsulation, which allows for the hiding of an object's internal details and the exposure of only its public interface. This helps to prevent accidental modification of an object's state and promotes modularity and code reuse. Inheritance is another important concept in OOP, which allows for the creation of new classes that inherit the properties and behaviors of existing classes. This helps to reduce code duplication and allows for the creation of more specialized classes. Polymorphism is also a key feature of OOP, which allows for the same method to behave differently depending on the context in which it is used. This helps to make code more flexible and adaptable to changing requirements.
Principle 1: Become genuinely interested in other people.
Principle 2: Smile.
Principle 3: Use the person's name.
Principle 4: Be a good listener.
Principle 5: Talk in terms of the other person's interests.
Principle 6: Make the other person feel important - and do it sincerely.
Principle 7: The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.
Principle 8: Show respect for the other person's opinions.
Principle 9: If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.
Principle 10: Begin in a friendly way.
Principle 11: Get the other person saying yes, yes immediately.
Principle 12: Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.
Principle 13: Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers.
Principle 14: Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.
Principle 15: Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires.
Principle 16: Appeal to the nobler motives.
Principle 17: Dramatize your ideas.
Principle 18: Throw down a challenge.
Principle 19: Begin with praise and honest appreciation.
Principle 20: Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.
Principle 21: Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.
Principle 22: Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.
Principle 23: Let the other person save face.
It's not my job to manage someone eles's expectations. It's their job to manage thier own expectations. It's my job to do my best and to communicate clearly. Extreme Programming
